docs.abstract: Benchmark bottles were always a splurge. But an increasing concentration of wealth has put them out of reach for all but the richest connoisseurs.
docs.snippet: Benchmark bottles were always a splurge. But an increasing concentration of wealth has put them out of reach for all but the richest connoisseurs.
docs.lead_paragraph: Among the many ways the rich are different from you and me: Only they can afford grand cru Burgundy.

headline.main: How Income Inequality Has Erased Your Chance to Drink the Great Wines

docs.abstract: A Federal Reserve survey of family finances shows that inequality was high last year. It’s likely to worsen because of the pandemic.
docs.snippet: A Federal Reserve survey of family finances shows that inequality was high last year. It’s likely to worsen because of the pandemic.
docs.lead_paragraph: American families shored up their savings substantially between 2016 and 2019, according to Federal Reserve data released on Monday, but wealth inequality remained stubbornly high — and that was before the coronavirus pandemic took hold.

headline.main: Even as Americans Grew Richer, Inequality Persisted
headline.print_headline: Savings Rise But Fed Sees Persistent Inequality

docs.abstract: In a year racked by crises, many important issues have been overshadowed. Times readers weighed in on what they want the candidates to address.
docs.snippet: In a year racked by crises, many important issues have been overshadowed. Times readers weighed in on what they want the candidates to address.
docs.lead_paragraph: This year’s presidential election has been shaped by crises: Protests over police brutality and systemic racism. Fears about safe voting and election integrity. And above all, the devastating human and economic toll of the coronavirus.

headline.main: What Topics Do Our Readers Want Trump and Biden to Debate?
headline.print_headline: What Issues Do You Want Addressed in the Debate?

docs.abstract: The pandemic is causing inequality to soar, but increasingly the privileged are discovering that they can’t bend the world to their will.
docs.snippet: The pandemic is causing inequality to soar, but increasingly the privileged are discovering that they can’t bend the world to their will.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Monday, a group of Upper West Siders who had organized against the placement of 235 homeless men in a residential hotel in their neighborhood received some unwelcome news. On the morning the men were supposed to move far downtown, a judge ruled that they could remain where they were. Relocating would be too disruptive and traumatic to people piecing their lives back together amid a pandemic

headline.main: The Rich in New York Confront an Unfamiliar Word: No
headline.print_headline: The Privileged Hear a Curious Word: ‘No’

docs.abstract: Sunday’s election is seen as a referendum on Evo Morales, who lifted many out of poverty in his 14 years as president, but whose policies and tone divided the country.
docs.snippet: Sunday’s election is seen as a referendum on Evo Morales, who lifted many out of poverty in his 14 years as president, but whose policies and tone divided the country.
docs.lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia — Adalid Zelada fully supported Evo Morales when Bolivia chose him as the country’s first Indigenous president in 2005.

headline.main: In Election, Bolivia Confronts Legacy of Ousted Socialist Leader
headline.print_headline: Bolivian Election Is Seen as Referendum on an Ousted Socialist Leader

docs.lead_paragraph: This pivotal moment isn’t just the result of four years of Donald Trump. It’s the culmination of 50 years of social decay.

headline.main: How to Actually Make America Great
headline.print_headline: How to Actually Make America Great

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: The Upswing: How America Came Together a Century Ago and How We Can Do It Again (Book)

docs.abstract: In America’s bizarre electoral system, some votes are more equal than others.
docs.snippet: In America’s bizarre electoral system, some votes are more equal than others.
docs.lead_paragraph: I spent about an hour over the weekend filling out my ballot for the 2020 general election. As an immigrant from a country where elections were not free until 1994, I understand the privilege of the franchise. Every two years, when it’s time to vote in national elections, I rip open my voting packet with a sense of sacred, nerdy seriousness. I’ll even study the positions of the candidates for school board. But that feeling never lasts; by the time I finish filling in all the bubbles, I am bitter and angry, weighed down by the pointlessness of the whole exercise.

headline.main: California’s 40 Million People Are Sick of Being Ignored
headline.print_headline: California’s 40 Million People Are Sick of Being Ignored

docs.abstract: A surge in worldwide demand by educators for low-cost laptops has created shipment delays and pitted desperate schools against one another. Districts with deep pockets often win out.
docs.snippet: A surge in worldwide demand by educators for low-cost laptops has created shipment delays and pitted desperate schools against one another. Districts with deep pockets often win out.
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Guilford County Schools in North Carolina spent more than $27 million to buy 66,000 computers and tablets for students over the summer, the district ran into a problem: There was a shortage of cheap laptops, and the devices wouldn’t arrive until late October or November.

headline.main: The Digital Divide Starts With a Laptop Shortage
headline.print_headline: Schoolchildren Stalled for Months by a Growing Laptop Shortage

docs.abstract: Television taught me how to move between social classes — but at what cost?
docs.snippet: Television taught me how to move between social classes — but at what cost?
docs.lead_paragraph: At first, I thought class was about money. “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air” taught me that it wasn’t.

headline.main: Everything I Know About Elite America I Learned From ‘Fresh Prince’ and ‘West Wing’
headline.print_headline: ‘I’m Not Rich, I Just Watch a Lot of TV’

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air (TV Program)

docs.abstract: Some corporate bosses who received stock awards this year are sitting on gains of millions of dollars.
docs.snippet: Some corporate bosses who received stock awards this year are sitting on gains of millions of dollars.
docs.lead_paragraph: Even as millions of people have lost their jobs during the pandemic, the soaring stock market since the spring has delivered outsize gains to the wealthiest Americans. And few among the superrich have done as well as corporate executives who received stock awards this year.

headline.main: While Millions Lost Jobs, Some Executives Made Millions in Company Stock
headline.print_headline: C.E.O.s Reap Riches In Stock Amid Crisis
